title-group.article-title: Pre-ICU Management of Patients With Head Trauma

article-meta.aff: 2Department of Neurological Surgery, University of California, San Francisco, California

author-notes.corresp: Julin F. Tang, MD, MS, FCCM, Department of Anesthesia and Perioperative Care, University of California, San Francisco, 1001 Potrero Avenue, Room 4F4, San Francisco, CA 94110; e-mail: tangj@anesthesia.ucsf.edu.

abstract.p: Patients presenting with traumatic brain injury (TBI) pose special challenges for critical care personnel throughout the hospital, especially for emergency department and operating room personnel who care for TBI patients during their initial evaluation. Many of these patients proceed from the emergency department to an operating room for emergent cranial decompression en route to the ICU. At the authors’ hospital, a level I trauma center, steps have been taken to improve treatment in this pre-ICU care setting. In this report, the authors describe changes that have been made over time in the care of patients with TBI and the improved patient mortality that occurred after the introduction of these practice changes. The measures consisted of early goal-directed fluid resuscitation to correct intravascular volume depletion and vigilant hemodynamic monitoring by arterial line, central venous pressure, and transesophageal echocardiography. Despite these improved results, additional studies are needed to better define the best early treatment practices for the TBI patient.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: There are approximately 275 000 head injury patients hospitalized annually in the United States, requiring either minor or major medical care depending on the severity of injury. More than 50 000 patients with severe head injury die from their traumatic brain injury (TBI). The overall mortality rate for head injury is between 20% and 25%; TBI accounts for 30% to 35% of all deaths from acute trauma in the Unite States.1

Previous work has demonstrated a detrimental effect on survival and outcome of hypotensive episodes prior to arrival at the hospital, in the emergency department or ICU following TBI.2-5 At our trauma center, we have an occurrence of about 30 patients with severe TBI each year requiring transfer emergently from the emergency department to the operating room for urgent decompressive craniotomy or craniectomy. Our interest in this patient population rose during the period from 1996 to 2004, when we documented 20 patients who suffered sudden cardiac arrest after emergency dural opening. This spate of cases prompted a retrospective study and a review of our practice.

Evidence from published literature strongly supports the clinical goals of preventing hypoxemia and hypotension after TBI.3 However, we found that TBI patients needing emergent decompressive craniotomy or craniectomy may be transported from the emergency department to the operating room with very little, if any, organized treatment strategy based on these principles. Care of these patients requires initial providers to have the basic knowledge of the physiologic reflexes that are activated by TBI, including a fundamental understanding of the Cushing reflex, together with an organized approach to intraoperative hemodynamic management to give patients their best chance of surviving and recovering from TBI.6 Their care also requires knowledge of the effects of anesthesia and other pharmacological agents on these critically ill patients.

sec.title: Initial Considerations in the Emergency Department
sec.p: Cerebral ischemia from hypotension and hypoxemia are recognized as the primary mechanism for secondary brain injury following traumatic head injury, contributing to both increased mortality and worsened neurologic outcome.7 “Cerebral tamponade” is a term that describes a severe rise of intracranial pressure (ICP) from the accumulation of hemorrhage or swelling within the confined intracranial space that severely reduces cerebral blood flow. Preservation of cerebral blood flow and maintenance of cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP), which is defined as mean arterial pressure (MAP)-ICP, are basic management principles guiding the treatment of patients with TBI.8,9 The development of cerebral tamponade will quickly lead to patient death unless treated.

The decrease in perfusion pressure to the injured brain secondary to intracranial bleeding and cerebral edema triggers robust sympathetic nervous system activation. An increase in ICP following TBI may cause a spectrum of cardiopulmonary hemodynamic responses, including systemic hypertension and a decrease in heart rate secondary to the Cushing reflex.10 The physiologic reactions of the circulation because of elevated ICP were first described by Dr Harvey Cushing in 1902.2 The reflex is composed of a triad of findings: (a) increased systemic blood pressure, (b) bradycardia, and (c) irregular respiratory pattern. In addition, the pulse pressure tends to increase or widen as the systolic blood pressure increases due to a Cushing reflex. The Cushing reflex represents a self-protective reflex attempt to maintain adequate cerebral perfusion. The vasopressor component of the Cushing response is caused by a sympathetic surge and catecholamine release, resulting in an initial increase in cardiac output and systemic vascular resistance.10 Sympathetic hyperactivity increases circulating catecholamine levels 3 to 7 times above normal and correlates with the severity of neurologic injury.11,12 Furthermore, blood flow goes where resistance is lowest and elevation of axial vascular resistance results in proportionately more cardiac output/O2 delivery going to the low vascular resistance circuits—the undamaged brain and its penumbra. This hyperdynamic vasoconstrictor response constitutes an intrinsic autoregulatory mechanism that works as a defense against cerebral ischemia.

Because the increase in the systemic blood pressure may occur without a significant rise in the heart rate, the cardiac output in these patients becomes more dependent on preload and stroke volume than on heart rate. Systemic hypertension arises from the strong sympathetic surge after TBI leading to an intense α-adrenergic vasoconstrictor effect. This physiologic response is almost the exact opposite to that seen in the majority of the patients with acute trauma whose initial presentations are characterized by hypotension and tachycardia.

In some TBI patients, tachycardia secondary to sympathetic hyperactivity and catecholamine release may be observed.10,11 Hypovolemia due to hemorrhage or from mannitol-induced diuresis can also contribute to tachycardia. These other influences can further confound the clinical hemodynamic assessment of patients following traumatic brain injury.13

Historically, a fluid restrictive approach has been recommended for patients with TBI to mitigate the development of cerebral edema. Additional measures to reduce ICP reduction include the use of mannitol to produce an osmotic diuresis and brain dehydration.14,15 It is also argued in the general trauma literature that avoiding restoration of normal blood pressure in trauma patients with hemorrhage by using a fluid restrictive approach may decrease the risk of clot dislodgement and the concurrent risk of new bleeding.16

Unfortunately, there are no data to support the notion that intravenous fluid administration and restoration of normal blood pressure will trigger or accelerate intracranial bleeding in patients with TBI.6 In fact, it was first shown in 1990 that higher blood pressure in the ICU management of TBI patients was beneficial in improving outcomes when patients were kept normovolemic and hyperdynamic by volume expansion and catecholamine infusion.17 Conversely, a negative fluid balance of more than 600 mL in patients with severe TBI has been associated with an adverse effect on outcome.14 The most recent Brain Trauma Foundation guideline recommends a goal for CPP parameters of 50 to 70 mm Hg.18,19 Administration of fluids and pressors to push CPP above 70 mm Hg should also be avoided to minimize the risk of inducing pulmonary complication (acute respiratory distress syndrome) or other unfavorable neurologic outcomes.20-22

sec.title: Intraoperative Considerations
sec.p: The need for emergent decompressive craniotomy or craniectomy to evacuate a hematoma and to relieve ICP depends on the severity of the brain injury. Recent studies have documented severe intraoperative hypotension (IH) occurring after opening of the dura in TBI patients; this response has stirred interest in basic and clinical research related in intracranial physiology.23,24 Following dural opening, a sudden reduction in sympathetic output on relief of the Cushing reflex may lead to a dramatic fall in systemic vascular resistance. This effect is a primary cause of IH following emergent brain decompression.25,26 Anesthetic agents that cause systemic vasodilation or myocardial depression may further exacerbate hypotension and worsen the magnitude and duration of IH, especially in the presence of uncorrected hypovolemia.25,26

Inhaled anesthetics, analgesics, and sedative agents have varying effects on cerebral blood flow, systemic vasomotor tone, and myocardial contractility.26 The most beneficial effect of these drugs is to reduce cerebral metabolic rate and decrease cerebral oxygen consumption, which in turn may prevent secondary damage to areas of low perfusion.27 The beneficial effect of these agents must be balanced against their adverse hemodynamic effects that can aggravate preexisting intracranial pathology and worsen outcome in TBI patients.19,28 There have been no outcome studies to date with respect to the choice of intraoperative use of inhaled anesthetics, analgesics, and sedatives in TBI. As part of our practice change over the past 7 years, we now support the practice of limiting inhaled anesthetics and analgesic sedation to prevent IH during emergent craniotomy or craniectomy while preserving a modest neuroprotective effect.

Preoperative heart rate, blood pressure, hematocrit, and base deficit can be unreliable indicators of intravascular volume status or predictors of hemodynamic stability during emergent decompressive craniotomy or craniectomy.10 Arterial blood gases are helpful in guiding correction needed to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation. Noninvasive monitors SpO2 and end-tidal CO2 should be kept above 98% and between 35 and 40 mm Hg, respectively. In addition, measurement of the central venous pressure may be helpful to assess volume and to trend volume status. In addition, since 2009 we have employed transesophageal echocardiography as an additional tool to assess volume status to provide an additional method for assessment of the intravascular volume. These measures can also be employed postoperatively in the ICU to optimize cerebral recovery.9

Current management protocols underscore the importance of maintaining target CPP during all phases of TBI patient care to prevent secondary brain injury. Intraoperative hypotension in patients with severe TBI with elevated ICP is associated with worsening patient outcome.6 This finding is corroborated by autopsy studies in which 60% to 90% of the head injury patients showed signs of brain ischemia.29,30 TBI patients with IH, defined as systolic blood pressure <90 mm Hg at any time during anesthetic management, even for short durations, had an 82% mortality and significant worsening of long-term outcome.6 It is worth noting that the recent definition of hypotension has increased the threshold of systolic blood pressure to <110 mm Hg.31 Therefore, prompt recognition and treatment of IH is essential because it comprises an important preventable contributor to secondary brain injury. It is imperative that anesthesiologists understand the preoperative risk factors for IH and pay meticulous attention to the maintenance of CPP in the perioperative setting. It is also important to understand the mechanism of vasomotor control and hemodynamic response following TBI in order to anticipate the potential hemodynamic consequences of the cessation of the Cushing response.

We have introduced practice changes in our perioperative management based on this understanding (Table 1). Specifically, we now stress maintenance of MAP, optimal fluid and blood product resuscitation, judicious administration of anesthetic agents, intense hemodynamic monitoring, and modification of surgical technique.32 These changes have significantly reduced the incidence of IH in patients with severe TBI undergoing emergent decompressive cranial surgery. After institution of our practice change, our patients have displayed significantly smaller and much more appropriate decreases in MAP after dural opening. There have been no sudden cardiac arrests related to the dural opening.

sec.p: Nevertheless, despite increased volume resuscitation guided by invasive CVP monitoring, reduced anesthetic dosing and vasopressor support some patients have still developed signs of peripheral vasomotor paralysis, possibly because of catecholamine receptor saturation and catecholamine-induced myocardial dysfunction.10,33 In the 20 patients who suffered intraoperative deaths, this vasomotor paralysis phenomenon explains the failure of resuscitation attempts with massive volume infusion and vasopressor support. The recent publication of the DECRA study claims that “in adults with severe diffuse traumatic brain injury and refractory intracranial hypertension, early bifrontal decompressive craniectomy decreased intracranial pressure and the length of the stay in the ICU but was associated with more unfavorable outcomes.”34 This finding emphasizes the need to consider intraoperative management seriously with the hope of improving long term mortality.

Based on our practice improvement, we believe in retrospect that the intraoperative deaths we observed previously with dural opening were caused by insufficient fluid replacement, producing a negative fluid balance that was further compounded by the osmotic effects of mannitol. The classic signs of hypovolemia such as low blood pressure and tachycardia may be concealed by the Cushing vasopressor effect. Thus, emergency department and anesthesia providers managing TBI patients should be vigilant that reliance on MAP, heart rate, hematocrit, and base deficit as indicators of intravascular volume status and hemodynamic stability may be entirely inadequate in the setting of severe TBI. We found no preoperative difference in these parameters between the intraoperative death and good outcome groups (Table 2). Our new approach to the preoperative care of severe TBI undergoing emergent cranial decompression supports the practice of maintaining and elevating MAP and CVP in the face of clinical signs of elevated ICP as an effective mechanism to prevent intraoperative hypotension and death during emergent craniotomy for severe TBI. This practice may also ameliorate the potentially pernicious effects of decreased cerebral blood flow during emergent craniotomy and help protect the injured brain from early ischemic insult. Since 2004, we had no incident of intraoperative cardiac arrest upon opening of the dura, reducing our facility’s intraoperative mortality rate from 8.3% to 0%. With further study and validation of this practice change, we may be able to substantially reduce or eliminate one major source of early mortality for patients undergoing emergency decompressive surgery for severe TBI. Hopefully, we may be able to shed some light on the variable results of early cranial decompression on long-term morbidity and mortality rate.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The purpose of this article has been to share with critical care providers what we have learned in comparing past conventional methods of care with newer resuscitation approaches. The results in our institution confirm that pre-ICU practices employing higher systolic and mean arterial pressure targets, modestly increased total fluid resuscitation volumes, enhanced hemodynamic monitoring, and limited dosing of anesthetic agents reduce the risk of severe hypotension during initial emergency decompressive surgery of severe TBI. This successful outcome has been based on better appreciation of the underlying pathophysiology of TBI and early recognition of the presenting clinical signs that prompt aggressive treatment.

One limitation of this presentation is that it lacks functional neurological outcome data between pre- and postchange groups of patients as a late endpoint measure. Our overall survival-to-hospital-discharge rate has shown significant improvement. The reasons for our improved outcomes are multifactorial and include ongoing modifications and adjustments to many aspects of care of patients with severe TBI. Although the intraoperative practice change we describe is likely a contributing factor, we cannot directly attribute these improvements in outcome to this alone. In addition, the changes made to our practice with TBI patients were not strictly protocolized with regard to target or upper limit of MAP, type and volume of fluid resuscitation, specified use of anesthetic agents, and type of vasopressor support across the many practitioners in our institution. Although it has been shown that the implementation of a clinical practice guidelines–based management protocol in patients with severe TBI was associated with a significant reduction in hospital and ICU mortality,35 this intervention pertained only to the ICU setting and did not include the operating room and intraoperative management of severe TBI cases. To date, no literature has been published, nor has any study been undertaken regarding efforts to protocolize intraoperative management of severe TBI. The absence of such a protocol makes it difficult to determine if there is indeed a relationship between the existence of an evidence-based intraoperative protocol and mortality rate among severe TBI cases. We theorize that this is in part difficult because many management decisions may be left to were left to the critical care practitioner to make, based on individual preferences and circumstances, and that this contributes further variances to clinical practice. Nevertheless, it is worth stressing that since the introduction of our practice change in 2004 to present, our level I trauma center has experienced no incident of intraoperative deaths during emergent decompressive craniotomy or crainectomy. More comprehensive studies are needed in establishing better standards for managing hemodynamics in patients with severe head trauma in the acute surgical phase of their treatment.
